title: What do two chords stacked on top of each other in ukulele tab mean? - Quora

response.answer_text: It's a formatting error. Pretty much the only time you'd see two rows of chords is if the instrument is capoed and the original key plus the transposed chords are given- but this is usually indicated on the chart. Chord substitutions aren't usually shown on a chord chart- you'd have to know what the subs are or write them in yourself. Just from looking at the chords themselves it's highly unlikely that it means you can choose to use either chord since most of the notes would clash. In other words, two players playing the chart would have to choose the same chord or have problems.
It's just bad word wrap. The chords for first line of the song “Here comes a thought” go: [Fmaj7]Take a moment to think of just flexibility love [E]and trust[E7]

No, you cannot use either chord as options. Chords are your palette of tones and mood just like an artist chooses tones and values of color. If you play the whole song with the top chords only then play it again with the bottom chords, you’ve just played two different songs. Or maintaining the metaphor - you’ve just painted two entirely different pictures. I’d definitely go with the bad word wrap.
It means you can use either chord or alternate to your desire. Simple as that.
I play a line with the first chord, then add in the second one while singing.
